Definition: Given a context and a verb separated by a newline character, you have to determine if the verb is static. A verb is static if it is about an event that doesn't change or it happens regularly. Output "Yes" if the verb is static and "No" otherwise.

Positive Examples.input:
New York (is) on the east coast. 
 Verb: is
Positive Examples.explanation: This is a good example. New York always is on the east coast.

Positive Examples.input:
Suspected bombs exploded outside the U.S. embassies in the Kenyan and Tanzanian capitals Friday, (killing) dozens of people, witnesses said. 
 Verb: killing
Positive Examples.explanation: In this example, killing is not static because it's restricted to a specific period.

Positive Examples.input:
He cannot decide for himself. The one that (decides) for him is me, his father.  
 Verb: decides
Positive Examples.explanation: In this example, his father always decides for him, and it happens regularly. So, it's a static verb.

Negative Examples.input:
He (is) a brave man. 
 Verb: is
Negative Examples.explanation: Being brave is static, so the answer is incorrect.

Negative Examples.input:
In Washington today, the Federal Aviation Administration (released) air traffic control tapes from the night the TWA Flight eight hundred went down. 
 Verb: released
Negative Examples.explanation: In this example, "released" happened in the past and it's not static.

Negative Examples.input:
" We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it, and we thought that's where it would stop. " He also talked about his " second job " as the group's cameraman, and having to wear four pairs of gloves to (work) the clockwork camera.  
 Verb: work
Negative Examples.explanation: In this example, "work" happens regularly. So, the answer is incorrect, and it's static.

Instances.input:
The blast in Nairobi occurred at about 10:35 a.m. ( 0735 GMT ) Friday, (toppling) a crowded building toward the embassy and a street packed with cars, trucks and buses.  
 Verb: toppling

Terrorist bombings at U.S. embassies in Kenya and Tanzania blew apart buildings and buses, trapping people under slabs of concrete and twisted steel that rescuers cleared with cranes, blow torches and bare hands. At least 82 were killed and more than 1,700 injured, officials (said) as dawn broke Saturday.  
 Verb: said

MANILA, Philippines ( AP ) _ Philippine President Joseph Estrada on Tuesday condemned the bombings of the U.S. embassies in Kenya and Tanzania and (offered) condolences to the victims and their families.  
 Verb: offered

The suspected car bombings occurred 700 kilometers ( 450 miles ) from each other but just minutes apart on Friday, turning busy streets in two African capitals into bloody piles of concrete and knots of steel.  This (appears) to have been a very well-coordinated, very well-planned attack _ clearly not the work of amateurs,  U.S. National Security Council spokesman P.J. Crowley said in Washington.  
 Verb: appears

FBI officials said they were not certain whether Stauber or Gingrich had been involved in antiabortion activities. The two men are believed to (live) in the Cleveland area.  
 Verb: live

And it stresses that every nation  has the duty to refrain from organizing, instigating, assisting or participating in terrorist acts in another state.  The almost simultaneous attacks Aug. 7 at the U.S. embassies in Nairobi, Kenya, and Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, (killed) 257 people and injured more than 5,500.  
 Verb: killed

Steve Hurst has that. The US military buildup in the Persian gulf continues apace, more planes (headed) from the united states and senior officials say Iraq's president Saddam Hussein can expect punishing air strikes to continue well into the future if he does n't stop building biological and chemical weapons.  
 Verb: headed

It was definitely a bomb,  said a U.S. Embassy official in Nairobi, who refused to identify himself.  You can see a huge crater behind the building, and a bomb went off at the embassy in Tanzania at the same time,  he (said).  
 Verb: said
